column2: CHAPTER XXXII.
column3: CHAPTER thirty two.

column2: WHEN I got there it was all still and Sunday-like, and hot and sunshiny; the hands was gone to the fields; and there was them kind of faint dronings of bugs and flies in the air that makes it seem so lonesome and like everybody's dead and gone; and if a breeze fans along and quivers the leaves it makes you feel mournful, because you feel like it's spirits whisperingspirits that's been dead ever so many yearsand you always think they're talking about _you_.
column3: WHEN I got there it was all still and Sunday like, and hot and sunshiny; the hands was gone to the fields; and there was them kind of faint dronings of bugs and flies in the air that makes it seem so lonesome and like everybody's dead and gone; and if a breeze fans along and quivers the leaves it makes you feel mournful, because you feel like it's spirits whispering  spirits that's been dead ever so many years  and you always think they're talking about underscore you underscore.

column2: As a general thing it makes a body wish _he_ was dead, too, and done with it all.
column3: As a general thing it makes a body wish underscore he underscore was dead, too, and done with it all.

column2: Phelps' was one of these little one-horse cotton plantations, and they all look alike.
column3: Phelps' was one of these little one horse cotton plantations, and they all look alike.

column2: A rail fence round a two-acre yard; a stile made out of logs sawed off and up-ended in steps, like barrels of a different length, to climb over the fence with, and for the women to stand on when they are going to jump on to a horse; some sickly grass-patches in the big yard, but mostly it was bare and smooth, like an old hat with the nap rubbed off; big double log-house for the white folkshewed logs, with the chinks stopped up with mud or mortar, and these mud-stripes been whitewashed some time or another; round-log kitchen, with a big broad, open but roofed passage joining it to the house; log smoke-house back of the kitchen; three little log nigger-cabins in a row t'other side the smoke-house; one little hut all by itself away down against the back fence, and some outbuildings down a piece the other side; ash-hopper and big kettle to bile soap in by the little hut; bench by the kitchen door, with bucket of water and a gourd; hound asleep there in the sun; more hounds asleep round about; about three shade trees away off in a corner; some currant bushes and gooseberry bushes in one place by the fence; outside of the fence a garden and a watermelon patch; then the cotton fields begins, and after the fields the woods.
column3: A rail fence round a two acre yard; a stile made out of logs sawed off and up ended in steps, like barrels of a different length, to climb over the fence with, and for the women to stand on when they are going to jump on to a horse; some sickly grass patches in the big yard, but mostly it was bare and smooth, like an old hat with the nap rubbed off; big double log house for the white folks  hewed logs, with the chinks stopped up with mud or mortar, and these mud stripes been whitewashed some time or another; round log kitchen, with a big broad, open but roofed passage joining it to the house; log smoke house back of the kitchen; three little log nigger cabins in a row t'other side the smoke house; one little hut all by itself away down against the back fence, and some outbuildings down a piece the other side; ash hopper and big kettle to bile soap in by the little hut; bench by the kitchen door, with bucket of water and a gourd; hound asleep there in the sun; more hounds asleep round about; about three shade trees away off in a corner; some currant bushes and gooseberry bushes in one place by the fence; outside of the fence a garden and a watermelon patch; then the cotton fields begins, and after the fields the woods.

column2: I went around and clumb over the back stile by the ash-hopper, and started for the kitchen.
column3: I went around and clumb over the back stile by the ash hopper, and started for the kitchen.

column2: When I got a little ways I heard the dim hum of a spinning-wheel wailing along up and sinking along down again; and then I knowed for certain I wished I was deadfor that _is_ the lonesomest sound in the whole world.
column3: When I got a little ways I heard the dim hum of a spinning wheel wailing along up and sinking along down again; and then I knowed for certain I wished I was dead  for that underscore is underscore the lonesomest sound in the whole world.

column2: I went right along, not fixing up any particular plan, but just trusting to Providence to put the right words in my mouth when the time come; for I'd noticed that Providence always did put the right words in my mouth if I left it alone.
column3: I went right along, not fixing up any particular plan, but just trusting to Providence to put the right words in my mouth when the time come; for I'd noticed that Providence always did put the right words in my mouth if I left it alone.

column2: When I got half-way, first one hound and then another got up and went for me, and of course I stopped and faced them, and kept still.
column3: When I got half-way, first one hound and then another got up and went for me, and of course I stopped and faced them, and kept still.

column2: And such another powwow as they made!
column3: And such another powwow as they made!

column2: In a quarter of a minute I was a kind of a hub of a wheel, as you may sayspokes made out of dogscircle of fifteen of them packed together around me, with their necks and noses stretched up towards me, a-barking and howling; and more a-coming; you could see them sailing over fences and around corners from everywheres.
column3: In a quarter of a minute I was a kind of a hub of a wheel, as you may say  spokes made out of dogs  circle of fifteen of them packed together around me, with their necks and noses stretched up towards me, a barking and howling; and more a coming; you could see them sailing over fences and around corners from everywheres.

column2: A nigger woman come tearing out of the kitchen with a rolling-pin in her hand, singing out, "Begone _you_ Tige! you Spot! begone sah!" and she fetched first one and then another of them a clip and sent them howling, and then the rest followed; and the next second half of them come back, wagging their tails around me, and making friends with me.
column3: A nigger woman come tearing out of the kitchen with a rolling pin in her hand, singing out, "Begone underscore you underscore t i g e! you Spot! begone s a h!" and she fetched first one and then another of them a clip and sent them howling, and then the rest followed; and the next second half of them come back, wagging their tails around me, and making friends with me.

column2: There ain't no harm in a hound, nohow.
column3: There ain't no harm in a hound, nohow.

column2: And behind the woman comes a little nigger girl and two little nigger boys without anything on but tow-linen shirts, and they hung on to their mother's gown, and peeped out from behind her at me, bashful, the way they always do.
column3: And behind the woman comes a little nigger girl and two little nigger boys without anything on but tow linen shirts, and they hung on to their mother's gown, and peeped out from behind her at me, bashful, the way they always do.

column2: And here comes the white woman running from the house, about forty-five or fifty year old, bareheaded, and her spinning-stick in her hand; and behind her comes her little white children, acting the same way the little niggers was doing.
column3: And here comes the white woman running from the house, about forty five or fifty year old, bareheaded, and her spinning stick in her hand; and behind her comes her little white children, acting the same way the little niggers was doing.

column2: She was smiling all over so she could hardly standand says:
column3: She was smiling all over so she could hardly stand  and says:

column2: It's _you_, at last!_ain't_ it?
column3: It's underscore you underscore, at last!underscore ain't underscore it?

column2: I out with a "Yes'm" before I thought.
column3: I out with a "Yes'm" before I thought.

column2: She grabbed me and hugged me tight; and then gripped me by both hands and shook and shook; and the tears come in her eyes, and run down over; and she couldn't seem to hug and shake enough, and kept saying, "You don't look as much like your mother as I reckoned you would; but law sakes, I don't care for that, I'm so glad to see you!

column2: Dear, dear, it does seem like I could eat you up!
column3: Dear, dear, it does seem like I could eat you up!

column2: Children, it's your cousin Tom!tell him howdy."
column3: Children, it's your cousin Tom!  tell him howdy."

column2: But they ducked their heads, and put their fingers in their mouths, and hid behind her.

column3: So she run on:

column2: Lize, hurry up and get him a hot breakfast right awayor did you get your breakfast on the boat?
column3: Lize, hurry up and get him a hot breakfast right away  or did you get your breakfast on the boat?

column2: I said I had got it on the boat.
column3: I said I had got it on the boat.

column2: So then she started for the house, leading me by the hand, and the children tagging after.
column3: So then she started for the house, leading me by the hand, and the children tagging after.

Now I can have a underscore good underscore look at you; and, laws a me, I've been hungry for it a many and a many a time, all these long years, and it's come at last!

column2: Where'd she get aground?"

column2: That didn't help me much, though; for I didn't know the names of bars down that way.

column2: We blowed out a cylinder-head."
column3: We blowed out a cylinder head."

column2: Good gracious! anybody hurt?
column3: Good gracious! anybody hurt?

column3: Two years ago last Christmas your uncle Silas was coming up from Newrleans on the old Lally Rook, and she blowed out a cylinder head and crippled a man.

column3: Your uncle Silas knowed a family in Baton Rouge that knowed his people very well.

column2: She stooped down quick at the foot of the bed and give me a pull, and out I come; and when he turned back from the window there she stood, a-beaming and a-smiling like a house afire, and I standing pretty meek and sweaty alongside.

column2: But there warn't no time to swap knives; the old man grabbed me by the hand and shook, and kept on shaking; and all the time how the woman did dance around and laugh and cry; and then how they both did fire off questions about Sid, and Mary, and the rest of the tribe.

column2: But if they was joyful, it warn't nothing to what I was; for it was like being born again, I was so glad to find out who I was.
column3: But if they was joyful, it warn't nothing to what I was; for it was like being born again, I was so glad to find out who I was.

column2: Well, they froze to me for two hours; and at last, when my chin was so tired it couldn't hardly go any more, I had told them more about my familyI mean the Sawyer familythan ever happened to any six Sawyer families.
column3: Well, they froze to me for two hours; and at last, when my chin was so tired it couldn't hardly go any more, I had told them more about my family  I mean the Sawyer family  than ever happened to any six Sawyer families.

column2: Which was all right, and worked first-rate; because _they_ didn't know but what it would take three days to fix it.

column2: Now I was feeling pretty comfortable all down one side, and pretty uncomfortable all up the other.

column2: Being Tom Sawyer was easy and comfortable, and it stayed easy and comfortable till by and by I hear a steamboat coughing along down the river.
column3: Being Tom Sawyer was easy and comfortable, and it stayed easy and comfortable till by and by I hear a steamboat coughing along down the river.

column2: Then I says to myself, s'pose Tom Sawyer comes down on that boat?
